title: Why do you write stories? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because if I didn’t, the voice in my head would never stop. I’m an active, outgoing guy by nature. I speak well and I’ve even been referred to as “charming” enough times that I almost allow myself to believe it. I’ve got my life together. I’ve got direction, man. Big boy responsibilities, even. But my brain—my brain is a chaotic mess of ten different perspectives of every situation, snapshots of people’s eye flutters and voice inflections, what-ifs, coulda-beens, furniture details, anxieties, angers, pop culture references, fleeting obsessions, microcosmic realizations, deep thoughts, and so much more stuff that I’ll never ever explore it fully in three (or four) lives. There’s a voice in there making sense of all those thoughts. It’s different than my own speaking voice. It’s more assertive, darkly funny, irreverent, world-weary. When I write, that voice takes shape. A lot of times I don’t want to write. It’s not always due to my own inherent human laziness, though sometimes it is. Most times, however, it’s because I’d like to keep all that stuff bottled inside me and maintain a firm grip on what’s displayed in a public forum. The voice doesn’t always reflect what I want to present to the public. Sometimes writing is not a clean, fun thing for me—it’s a pithy, greasy, dirty rollercoaster ride with no discernible end. And it can be exhausting. But I do it anyway. I make a living at it, as a matter of fact. When I write copy for companies or write stories for the newspaper I am an editor at, the words are fairly regimented and straightforward. It’s more clinical than creative, though the voice always manages to sneak in there anyway. When I write for myself, however, or I’m writing for a publication with a more liberal bent, I can exercise my “real” voice. That’s when the floodgates open a little wider. And that, my friend, is when my true inner voice gets to saddle up. That’s why I write—because it’s in there, and it has something to say, and it’s only happy if it gets on that mean horse and rides.

Ever since I was a kid, I actually had a vivid imagination, and while one of my outlets was drawing. There were moments that I can’t put things on paper. It’s like this itching thought at the top of my head that wanted to be explained. Often stories I’ve written started with either a question or an actual movie like scene in my head that just won’t stop bugging me either when I slept or when I daydream on the bus. Eventually, I started writing it down on my journals, and over a few weeks I began plotting it out as a story. I knew some of what I wrote was inspired by the books I’ve read, as if a smug inner side of me kept whispering things like “we can write something better than the book” but truthfully I couldn’t. Often, I share my stories to my close friends. They’d encourage me to finish the stories because if it was something I genuinely wrote and a story I’d like to read, there might be others out there who’d like it or find it good. I was never really too confident with my writing style either. Yet, with a lot of encouragement, I just kept writing. Usually, I would write out the plot, or whoever the character that bugs my consciousness. Sometimes my ideas sucks, but there are some that my friends and a ton of online readers kept telling me it’s good. Personally…I write as a way to find even a small piece of escape from Reality. I find fun in world building and creating adventures for my characters. Sometimes they are really grim stories, others are fantasy filled. But I just simply find joy with making a story that I personally would drop anything and sit down and read about. So, idk, maybe others see that in my stories, or the bunch of grammatical errors that would urge them to strangle me too haha.
